item.title: Radovan Karadzic, a Bosnian Serb, Is Convicted of Genocide
item.description: A United Nations tribunal for the former Yugoslavia found Mr. Karadzic guilty of war crimes and sentenced him to 40 years in prison.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Robin Van Lonkhuijsen
item.media:description: Radovan Karadzic, second from right, at the United Nations tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in The Hague on Thursday.

item.title: Egypt Continues Crackdown on Groups Documenting Government Abuse
item.description: The authorities pressed their case against the founders of two prominent human rights organizations, including charges of illegal foreign funding.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Arab Network for Human Rights Information
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Expanding Portraits of Brussels Bombers, Ibrahim and Khalid el-Bakraoui
item.description: The brothers, who were among three suicide bombers who carried out the Brussels attacks on Tuesday, had violent criminal records.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alas, Poor William Shakespeare. Where Does His Skull Rest?
item.description: Researchers have uncovered evidence that they say indicates his skull was stolen from his grave by a local doctor in 1794.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA
item.media:description: The grave of William Shakespeare inside Holy Trinity Church in Stratford-upon-Avon.

item.title: Brussels Attacks Add Urgency to Debate Over Britain’s E.U. Membership
item.description: A former director of the British intelligence service said on Thursday that the security of the nation would benefit if it departed from the bloc.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Jian Ghomeshi, Former Canadian Radio Host, Acquitted of Sexual Assault
item.description: The judge said the three women who testified against Mr. Ghomeshi undermined their credibility by not disclosing aspects of their relationships with him.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Chris Young/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jian Ghomeshi, a well-known Canadian musician and former radio host, arriving at a Toronto courthouse on Thursday for the verdict in his sexual assault trial.

item.title: To Beat the Rush, Americans Rush to Cuba, Overloading Services
item.description: The huge increase in American travel to Cuba is leading to shortages in food, gas and hotels rooms, plus a sharp rise in prices that will only steepen.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists on Wednesday along Obispo Boulevard, a street in central Havana known for restaurants, live music, bars and souvenir shops.

item.title: Names of the Brussels Victims Emerge Online, One by One
item.description: Families and friends are turning to social media to find out the fates of the missing.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS
item.media:description: Passengers were evacuated from the Brussels airport after Tuesday’s deadly attack.

item.title: Brussels Attack Lapses Acknowledged by Belgian Officials
item.description: The justice and interior ministers said officials might have been lax in passing along information about a terrorism suspect and offered to resign.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN, ALISSA J. RUBIN and LILIA BLAISE
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers outside the Brussels courthouse where Salah Abdeslam, a suspect in the Paris attacks, appeared on Thursday. The hearing was postponed until April 7.

item.title: One Traveler May Have Brought Zika to the Americas in 2013
item.description: A study says the virus probably arrived months before the 2014 soccer World Cup in Brazil, but others say the study was too limited to draw such a specific conclusion.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Brazil’s soccer team celebrated its victory in the Confederations Cup tournament in Rio de Janeiro in June 2013. In a study of the Zika virus’s genome, scientists noted that it was possible the virus arrived during the tournament.

item.title: Iraq Retakes ISIS-Held Villages Outside Mosul
item.description: An American officer confirmed that four villages had been recaptured but said this did not necessarily mean a long-awaited assault on Mosul had begun.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: John McCain: Salute to a Communist
item.description: “For Whom the Bell Tolls” was my favorite novel, and its hero, Robert Jordan, my literary idol. Like him, Delmer Berg fought in Spain, for love.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MCCAIN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on the Brussels Attacks
item.description: Will Europe pull up the drawbridge?
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Dilma Rousseff, President of Brazil, Resists Calls for Her Resignation
item.description: Despite the scandals engulfing her government, Ms. Rousseff said in an interview on Thursday that she would appeal any vote to impeach her.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Brazilian president, Dilma Rousseff, in her office in the Palácio do Planalto in Brasília on Thursday.

item.title: Hong Kong Bookseller Returns From Mainland China, Denying He Was Abducted
item.description: The disappearance of Lee Bo and four other people associated with Mighty Current Media drew concern over the state of media freedom in the semiautonomous city.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A missing-person notice for Lee Bo during a protest in Hong Kong in January. He was one of five people associated with the company Mighty Current Media to have disappeared, only to emerge in mainland China, apparently in detention.

item.title: U.S. Indicts 7 Iranians in Cyberattacks on Banks and a Dam
item.description: The indictment is the first time that the Obama administration has sought action against Iranians for a wave of computer attacks that began in 2011.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Israel Soldier Detained in Shooting of Palestinian
item.description: A video captured the soldier shooting the Palestinian in the head as he lay motionless on the ground. The man had just attacked another soldier.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The bodies of two Palestinians, including Abed al-Fatah al-Sharif, front, who were killed after wounding an Israeli soldier in a knife attack in the West Bank city of Hebron on Thursday.

item.title: Syrian Forces and ISIS Clash at Edge of Palmyra
item.description: Government troops and allied militias, backed by intensive Russian airstrikes, are fighting to retake the city, along with its majestic ancient ruins.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Obama Expresses Regret for U.S. Policies During Argentina’s ‘Dirty War’
item.description: The United States “has to examine its own policies as well, and its own past,” the president said at a memorial to victims of the war in 1970s and ’80s.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama with President Mauricio Macri of Argentina at the Parque de la Memoria in Buenos Aires on Thursday.

item.title: Myanmar Approves Cabinet Nominees, but Some Face Questions Over Credentials
item.description: Two of the picks list academic achievements from dubious institutions, prompting questions of the new government’s credibility.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: U Kyaw Win, who is expected to be the new minister of finance and planning, said he earned a master’s degree and a doctorate from Brooklyn Park University. But that institution has been identified as part of a network of websites run by a Pakistan-based company that has sold millions of dollars in fake diplomas.
